files.purpose: Boot sequence — the order in which the OS initializes

comments.BootSequence: The ordered initialization of a Charlotte container.

files.purpose: The five irreducible primitives of Charlotte

comments.NODE: Identity. Any uniquely identifiable entity in the graph.
comments.EDGE: Relationship. A typed, directed connection between two NODEs.
comments.METRIC: Quantitative signal. A measurable dimension attached to a NODE.
comments.SIGNAL: Event. A timestamped observation placed on a METRIC line.
comments.PROTOCOL: Rule. Business logic that governs graph evolution.
comments.FACT: The atomic unit of knowledge in Charlotte. Every piece of information is a FACT.

files.purpose: Core type system — collections, predicates, and constraints

comments.StructuralKnowledge: Relationship between object and concept. The web of typed edges.
comments.DeclarativeKnowledge: Object facts. Assertions that are true or false.
comments.ProceduralKnowledge: Rules and procedures. How to do things.
comments.HeuristicKnowledge: Rules of thumb. Approximate reasoning from observation.
comments.MetaKnowledge: Knowledge about knowledge. Self-awareness of the system.
comments.:ID: Unique identifier. Immutable. Set at FACT creation.
comments.:TYPE: Primitive type. One of NODE, EDGE, METRIC, SIGNAL, PROTOCOL.
comments.P0: Payload register 0. Type-specific. See primitive definition.

files.purpose: The serial reasoning architecture that distinguishes Charlotte

comments.ValuationLayer: The serial reasoning pipeline (METRIC → SIGNAL → PROTOCOL) that sits on top of the ontological graph (NODE + EDGE). The valuation layer is not traversed ambiguously — it is processed serially, like a signal processing pipeline. Every conclusion has a deterministic, traceable reasoning path back through the exact signals and metrics that produced it.
comments.OntologicalLayer: The structural knowledge graph (NODE + EDGE). Answers 'what exists' and 'how things relate.' Supports standard graph traversal and topological reasoning. This is the layer most KG implementations stop at.
comments.DiveLineProperty: Every conclusion in the valuation layer has a complete, serial, deterministic trace back to the raw metrics and graph entities that produced it. This trace is the dive line. It is never probabilistic. It is never approximate. It is the line.
comments.ObserverPerspective: The valuation layer is perspectival — it encodes the observer's judgment, not objective truth. Two observers looking at the same NODE+EDGE graph may place different SIGNALs on the same METRICs because they apply different thresholds and different PROTOCOLs. This is by design. The graph (facts) is shared. The valuation (interpretation) is scoped to the observer's microtheory.
comments.valuationChain: (valuationChain ?protocol ?signal ?metric ?node) The complete dive line from a protocol firing back to the entity it concerns. Every protocol must have at least one complete chain. If you cannot produce the chain, the protocol has no grounding and should not fire.

files.purpose: ALLEGORY.KRF — The Cave, The Swarm, and The Serengeti
Default attribute definitions — property vocabulary for NODEs
Default entity types — the NODE vocabulary

comments.Nascent: Just created. Not yet fully initialized.
comments.Dormant: Exists but not currently active. Can be reactivated.
comments.Archived: No longer active. Preserved for historical reference.
comments.Deceased: Terminal state. The entity has ceased to exist.
comments.IndividualEntity: A single identifiable individual: a person, an animal, a machine.
comments.GroupEntity: A collection of individuals: a herd, a team, a fleet.
comments.AssetEntity: A thing of value: a violin, a truck, a building.
comments.LocationEntity: A place: a barn, a venue, a warehouse, a coordinate.
comments.EventEntity: An occurrence: a birth, a delivery, a performance.
comments.DocumentEntity: A record: an invoice, a certificate, a report.
comments.::LABEL: Human-readable name for the entity.

files.purpose: knowledge/declarative/people.krf
Default assumptions and rules of thumb

comments.RecencyWindow: Default: a signal younger than 30 days is fresh. Domain-overridable.

files.purpose: Default metric bounds and tolerances

comments.GraphNodeEdgeRatio: Healthy graphs have roughly 2 edges per node on average.
comments.MinSignalFrequency: At least 1 signal per metric per period. Target: weekly.
comments.DormancyTimeout: 90 days without a signal suggests the NODE may be dormant.
comments.EpochUtilization: Fraction of the current epoch's timeline that has elapsed.

comments.ISGCompetitiveLandscapeMt: Competitive intelligence for Industrial Service Group (ISG). Maps 111+ competitors across 6 verticals (valves, compressors, motors, pumps, MRO distribution, specialty/turbo) with pricing benchmarks, market sizing, and competitive threat assessments.
comments.SetpointIS: Most dangerous direct valve competitor. 4-5x ISG valve ops. 65+ years, 400+ technicians, ValvKeep tracks 1.5M+ valves.
comments.OvationHoldings: PE-backed roll-up identical to ISG model. Midwest focus.
comments.AtlasCopco: Global #1. SMARTLINK IoT. 36% revenue from services.
comments.BlakePendleton: Primary direct compressor competitor. Same SE territory, multi-brand, services ALL brands.
comments.OTCIndustrial: Most structurally analogous to ISG. PE-backed, multi-brand, comparable scale.
comments.IPS: Largest motor service network in industry. PE-backed (Riverside). 1,800 technicians, 158 engineers.
comments.TimkenPowerSystems: Largest independent motor repair facility under one roof (180K sqft).
comments.DXPEnterprises: Strongest rotating equipment focus among public distributors. 6x ISG scale. Innovative Pumping Solutions division.
comments.FCXPerformance: Largest specialty flow control distributor in the US. 250+ service/repair technicians.
comments.GEVernova: Services 55%+ of backlog. Dominant installed base.
comments.SulzerTurbo: Houston = world's largest turbomachinery service center. 32 acres, 285K sq ft, 700+ employees.

comments.ISGProductCatalogMt: Complete product and service catalog for ISG's 16 subsidiary brands. Scraped from public websites 2026-02-12. Contains 1,152+ product entries with 362,000+ SKUs in backend e-commerce stores. This microtheory inherits from ISGCompetitiveLandscapeMt for cross-reference with competitor data.
comments.IndustrialProduct: A physical product, part, or piece of equipment sold or distributed by an ISG brand. Lives in the ontological layer as a NODE.
comments.IndustrialService: A service offering (repair, maintenance, field service, machining, etc.) provided by an ISG brand. Lives in the ontological layer as a NODE.
comments.EquipmentCategory: A product or service category (e.g., Safety Relief Valves, Compressors, Turbine Parts). Provides taxonomic structure for the catalog.
comments.OEMManufacturer: An original equipment manufacturer whose products are sold, serviced, or distributed by ISG brands.
comments.soldByBrand: (soldByBrand ?product ?brand) — EDGE linking a product/service to the ISG subsidiary that sells or provides it.
comments.inProductCategory: (inProductCategory ?product ?category) — EDGE linking a product to its top-level equipment category.
comments.inSubcategory: (inSubcategory ?product ?subcategory) — EDGE linking a product to its subcategory (manufacturer line, product type, etc.).
comments.partNumber: (partNumber ?product ?pn) — The manufacturer or distributor part number.
comments.manufacturer: (manufacturer ?product ?mfg) — The OEM or original manufacturer of the product.
comments.productUrl: (productUrl ?product ?url) — Source URL where the product is listed.
comments.hasSpec: (hasSpec ?product ?specName ?specValue) — A technical specification key-value pair attached to a product.
comments.oemCrossRef: (oemCrossRef ?product ?oemPartNumber) — OEM part number that an aftermarket product replaces or is equivalent to.
comments.turbineModel: (turbineModel ?product ?model) — Elliott YR turbine model designation (AYR, BYR, BYRH, CYR, DYR, TG Governor, PG Governor, etc.).
comments.backendSkuCount: (backendSkuCount ?brand ?category ?count) — Number of SKUs in the brand's backend e-commerce system that are not fully enumerable from public scraping.
comments.listPrice: (listPrice ?product ?usd) — Listed retail price in USD. This is a METRIC — a concrete measurement attached to a product NODE.
comments.listPriceLow: (listPriceLow ?product ?usd) — Low end of a price range in USD.
comments.listPriceHigh: (listPriceHigh ?product ?usd) — High end of a price range in USD.
comments.catalogProductCount: 1,152 distinct product and service entries scraped from 16 brand websites. Does not include the 362,000+ backend SKUs in e-commerce stores that require pagination or authentication to fully enumerate.

files.purpose: What is known, what is unknown, and open-world assumptions

comments.OpenWorldAssumption: If a fact is not in the graph, it is unknown — not false. Charlotte never assumes completeness unless explicitly told.
comments.completenessOf: (completenessOf Entity Dimension Level) — how complete is Entity along Dimension?
comments.KnownUnknown: An explicit record that a piece of knowledge is missing.
comments.unknownFact: (unknownFact Entity Attribute Reason) — we know this attribute should exist but don't have it.
comments.closedWorldFor: (closedWorldFor Microtheory Collection) — within this Mt, the collection is exhaustively enumerated.
comments.graphCoverage: (graphCoverage Dimension Percentage) — what fraction of the domain is represented?
comments.DeclarativeCoverage: Fraction of domain entities that have NODEs.
comments.StructuralCoverage: Fraction of known relationships that have EDGEs.
comments.TemporalCoverage: Fraction of the temporal spine that has SIGNALs.
comments.SpatialCoverage: Fraction of the spatial planes that are populated.
comments.HeuristicCoverage: Fraction of METRICs that have sufficient signal history.

files.purpose: Tracking where knowledge came from

comments.createdBy: Which agent or process created this FACT.
comments.derivedFrom: The upstream source from which this FACT was derived.
comments.confidenceScore: Confidence in this FACT. 0.0 = no confidence, 1.0 = certain.
comments.lastVerified: When this FACT was last independently verified.
comments.HumanObservation: A person directly observed and reported this fact.
comments.SensorReading: An automated sensor produced this fact.
comments.AlgorithmicInference: Charlotte inferred this fact from other facts.
comments.ExternalImport: This fact was imported from an external system.
comments.BootImage: This fact was part of the default OS image.

files.purpose: Knowledge about the knowledge structure itself

comments.SchemaDefinition: A statement about what structures are valid in this container.
comments.currentSchemaVersion: The version of the fact stack schema. Increment on breaking changes.

files.purpose: Validation constraints — rules that must hold at all times
Defines "Market Intelligence Report" as a Charlotte deliverable.

comments.CharlotteMarketIntelligenceMt: Market intelligence directive. Defines the deliverable type, primitives, report sections, generation protocol, provenance rules, and audience adaptation for Charlotte-generated market intelligence reports. A Charlotte-generated Market Intelligence Report is structurally equivalent to a $100K-500K consulting engagement.
comments.DeliverableType: A class of analytical output that Charlotte can generate from substrate data.
comments.MarketIntelligenceReport: A Charlotte-generated Market Intelligence Report is structurally equivalent to a $100K-500K consulting engagement. It contains the same sections, the same data depth, and the same analytical rigor — but is generated from substrate data in seconds, not months. The dive line traces every number back to its source study, sensor reading, or computed derivation.
comments.CompetitiveLandscapeReport: Focused competitive analysis — market share, threat matrix, positioning. A subset of a full Market Intelligence Report.
comments.PricingBenchmarkReport: Pricing intelligence across a market — ASPs, margins, premium tiers. Used for pricing strategy and competitive positioning.
comments.IndustryOverviewReport: High-level market sizing, segmentation, and trend analysis. The executive summary layer of a Market Intelligence Report.
comments.MarketStudy: A purchased or generated market research document. NODE type. Carries provenance metadata: publisher, date, page count, cost, methodology, scope, and confidence score.
comments.MarketSegment: A sliceable dimension of a market — by geography, product type, application, end-user, or technology. NODE type.
comments.CompanyProfile: A competitor or peer with structured financials — revenue, share, margin, manufacturing bases, distribution strategy. NODE type.
comments.MarketForecast: A projected market value at a future date with CAGR. METRIC type. Always carries a base year, forecast year, base value, forecast value, and compound annual growth rate.
comments.PricingBenchmarkMetric: A range-based price point (low/mid/high) for a product or service category. METRIC type. Used for pricing strategy and margin analysis.
comments.MarketTrend: A detected directional change in market conditions. SIGNAL type. Trends are observed patterns — not forecasts. They have direction (accelerating/decelerating), impact level, and ISG positioning notes.
comments.IndustryDriver: A force accelerating market growth. SIGNAL type. Drivers are external to any single company — they are macro forces.
comments.IndustryRestraint: A force decelerating market growth. SIGNAL type. Restraints are headwinds that slow or cap market expansion.
comments.ReportSectionType: A section type within a Market Intelligence Report.
comments.MarketOverviewSection: TAM/SAM/SOM with geographic breakdown. Uses MarketSizeWidget + StatGridWidget.
comments.MarketSegmentationSection: By product type, application, geography, end-user. Uses PieChartWidget + BarChartWidget.
comments.CompetitivePositioningSection: Market share, tier rankings, threat matrix. Uses ComparisonMatrixWidget.
comments.PricingIntelligenceSection: Benchmark ranges, margin analysis, pricing strategy. Uses PricingTableWidget.
comments.ForecastSection: CAGR projections, growth drivers, scenario modeling. Uses GrowthChartWidget.
comments.TrendAnalysisSection: Macro trends, technology shifts, regulatory changes. Uses IconGridWidget.
comments.SupplyChainSection: OEM mapping, distribution channels, routes-to-market. Uses FlowDiagramWidget.
comments.AftermarketSection: Parts revenue, service revenue, lifecycle economics. Uses UnitEconomicsWidget.
comments.SourceProvenanceSection: Study origins, methodology, confidence levels, cost of acquisition. Uses TwoColumnWidget.
comments.Protocol-GenerateMarketIntelligence: Master protocol for generating a Market Intelligence Report. Trigger: ManualInvocation (client requests market analysis). Condition: Domain has MarketSegment NODEs and CompanyProfile NODEs. Priority: 3. Steps: 1. Aggregate all MarketForecast METRICs by segment 2. Rank CompanyProfiles by revenue and threat level 3. Compile PricingBenchmarkMetrics into comparison matrix 4. Detect MarketTrends from SIGNAL history 5. Generate report sections in canonical order: MarketOverview → Segmentation → CompetitivePositioning → PricingIntelligence → Forecast → TrendAnalysis → SupplyChain → Aftermarket → SourceProvenance 6. Apply brand visual theme (SomeAI red for SomeAI deliverables, client theme for client-branded versions) 7. Attach SourceProvenance for every data point — dive line traces every number to its origin study or computation
comments.PremiumMarketStudy: A market study costing >$50,000. Premium studies carry higher confidence scores because they involve primary research: executive interviews, facility surveys, proprietary data.
comments.CostEquivalenceAxiom: Traditional market intelligence: $98K-500K per study, 3-6 months delivery, static PDF, outdated on delivery, no dive line. Charlotte market intelligence: $0 marginal cost per report, real-time generation, interactive visualization, traceable dive line from every number to its source study or sensor reading. The structural equivalence is not approximate — a Charlotte report contains the same sections, same data depth, same analytical rigor. The difference is substrate: Charlotte generates from living data, consultants generate from point-in-time interviews.

files.purpose: Charlotte's operational planning algorithm.

comments.OperationalAgent: An employee modeled as a foraging agent. Has position in the operational terrain, sight radius, visited history, current goal, and behavioral state. Each agent is an ant.
comments.OperationalGoal: A value-generating opportunity in the business terrain. Glows when discovered, dims when captured. Goals can be tasks, deals, deliverables, or any unit of value the operation is foraging for.
comments.OperationalTerrain: The business landscape. Open cells are actionable space. Obstacles are constraints — regulatory, resource, temporal, political. Generated via cellular automata from real operational data. Fog of war: agents only see what they've explored.
comments.PheromoneTrail: An append-only signal deposited on operational paths. Successful paths get reinforced (+0.5 on goal capture). All trails evaporate multiplicatively each tick (default ρ=0.995). What worked last quarter fades unless re-proven. Pheromone is emergent institutional memory — it encodes 'this path generated value' without anyone writing it down.
comments.OperationalPhase: An emergent state of the operation. Not assigned — detected from the ratio of explored terrain to total terrain. The operation naturally transitions through phases as agents forage.
comments.AStarPathfinding: Goal-directed movement for individual agents. Given an agent's current position and an assigned goal, A* finds the optimal path through the operational terrain using octile heuristic (8-directional). This is the 'next few moves' calculator. Each employee gets their own A* computation. Path recalculates every 40 ticks or when the current path is exhausted. Goal assignment uses nearest-unassigned with crowding penalty: effective_distance = octile_distance * (1 + other_agents_on_goal * 0.5) This prevents all agents from swarming the same goal.
comments.AntColonyOptimization: Collective intelligence through pheromone trails. Every cell an agent moves through gets a small pheromone deposit (+0.15). When an agent captures a goal, the entire path gets reinforced (+0.5). Exploration movement uses a weighted score: score = α·pheromone + γ·(exploration_bonus + visit_bonus) + noise Tunable parameters: α (pheromone weight)  = 0.40  — how much agents follow trails β (heuristic weight)  = 0.50  — how much A* guides pathfinding γ (exploration bonus)  = 0.30  — how much agents prefer unknown territory ρ (evaporation rate)  = 0.995 — how fast trails fade per tick sight radius          = 6     — how far agents can see Pheromone is capped at 1.0. Evaporation is multiplicative. Trails below 0.001 are zeroed. This prevents runaway reinforcement and ensures the operation adapts when the terrain changes.
comments.BoidsFlocking: Team coordination through three steering rules applied to each agent's movement vector before it executes: SEPARATION — avoid redundant work. If another agent is within collision radius, steer away. Two employees on the same task is waste. Repulsion force inversely proportional to distance. ALIGNMENT — shared heading. Agents within neighbor radius tend to align their movement direction. Teams working in the same area should be heading the same way, not thrashing. COHESION — stick together. Agents steer toward the average position of their local flock. Lone wolves forage less efficiently than coordinated teams. Tunable weights: w_separation = 1.5  — strongest force, avoid collision first w_alignment  = 1.0  — moderate, match team heading w_cohesion   = 0.8  — gentle pull toward team center neighbor_radius = 8 — how far to look for flockmates collision_radius = 2 — minimum separation distance The flocking vector is blended with the A* path vector and the ACO pheromone gradient to produce the final movement decision: final_heading = normalize( β·astar_direction + α·pheromone_gradient + w_sep·separation + w_ali·alignment + w_coh·cohesion + γ·exploration_noise )
comments.ExploringPhase: Less than 30% of terrain explored. Agents scatter. Exploration bonus γ dominates. Pheromone trails are sparse. This is a new business, a new market, a new team — the operation is mapping its own terrain. The algorithm favors discovery over efficiency.
comments.ConvergingPhase: 30-70% explored. Pheromone trails are forming. Agents start clustering on value-generating paths. The tension between exploration (γ) and exploitation (α) is at its peak. This is where the operation finds its rhythm — some agents scout while others harvest known trails.
comments.ExploitingPhase: Over 70% explored. Optimal paths are reinforced. Efficiency dominates. Pheromone weight α is most influential. But evaporation ensures complacency is temporary — trails fade if not re-walked. The operation is mature but never finished. Perpetual foraging.
comments.AgentState: Behavioral state of an operational agent.
comments.ExploringState: No assigned goal. Agent moves based on ACO score + Boids steering. Prefers unvisited cells. Periodically checks for available goals (every 15 ticks). This is an employee between tasks — still generating pheromone, still exploring, still useful.
comments.PathfindingState: Goal assigned. A* computed. Agent follows path, depositing pheromone at each step. Recalculates if goal is taken by another agent or if path is exhausted. This is an employee with a mission.
comments.CelebratingState: Goal captured. Path reinforced with bonus pheromone. Agent pauses for 30 ticks (recognition pulse), then reassigns. The celebration is functional — the reinforcement signal propagates institutional memory. Success must be visible to be repeatable.
comments.TerrainGenerator: Operational terrain is generated via cellular automata from real business data. The process: 1. Seed: 42% of cells are obstacles (from constraint density) 2. Smooth: 5 passes of cellular automata (walls >= 5 neighbors → wall) 3. Connect: flood-fill to find the largest connected region, wall off all disconnected pockets 4. Result: organic cave-like terrain where open space = actionable operations and walls = real constraints Terrain dimensions scale with operation: 160x120 = ~19,000 cells. A 10-employee operation might use 40x30. A 200-employee organization uses the full grid. Goals are placed randomly in open space. In production, goals are derived from SIGNAL streams — deals, tasks, deliverables, opportunities detected from operational signals.
comments.PerpetualForaging: The operational principle: there is no completion state. Goals are continuously generated from the SIGNAL stream. Captured goals reinforce trails. New goals appear in unexplored territory. Pheromone evaporates at rate ρ. The operation never stops foraging. Charlotte is not the queen — Charlotte is the pheromone itself. The invisible chemical trail that makes the colony intelligent without any ant understanding the whole.

files.purpose: Before-and-after Charlotte narratives for each business domain

comments.BeforeAfterNarrative: The master narrative strategy for Charlotte pitch decks. Every business exists in a 'before Charlotte' state — fragmented data, manual processes, invisible operations — and an 'after Charlotte' state — observed signals, unified substrate, autonomous intelligence. Charlotte does not change what the business does. It makes the business observable. The transformation from invisible to observed is the product.
comments.DomainPitchNarrative: A before/after narrative instantiated for a specific business domain. Each domain narrative captures the domain's pain state, Charlotte-powered state, transformation metric, hero stat, industry position, and contract.
comments.VisibilityTransformation: Invisible to observed. The business generates signals but nobody is watching. Charlotte places an observer on every metric line. What was dark becomes lit. This is the foundational transformation — without visibility, integration and intelligence are impossible.
comments.IntegrationTransformation: Siloed to unified. Data exists in 3, 5, 16 separate systems that never touch. Charlotte collapses them into a single substrate. Every NODE in every silo becomes part of one graph. Cross-silo EDGEs appear for the first time. This is the structural transformation.
comments.IntelligenceTransformation: Manual to autonomous. Humans perform pattern detection, threshold monitoring, and decision execution by hand. Charlotte's valuation layer (METRIC -> SIGNAL -> PROTOCOL) automates the reasoning chain. The human still decides strategy. Charlotte handles surveillance. This is the operational transformation.
comments.narrativeDomain: (narrativeDomain ?Narrative ?Domain) — the industry domain this narrative addresses.
comments.beforeState: (beforeState ?Narrative ?Description) — the fragmented, pre-Charlotte state of the business.
comments.afterState: (afterState ?Narrative ?Description) — the observed, Charlotte-powered state of the business.
comments.transformationMetric: (transformationMetric ?Narrative ?Metric) — the key metric that changes in the transformation.
comments.heroStat: (heroStat ?Narrative ?Stat) — the single most compelling number that carries the pitch.
comments.industryPosition: (industryPosition ?Narrative ?Position) — where Charlotte enters the industry value chain.
comments.contractValue: (contractValue ?Narrative ?Amount) — the dollar value of the Charlotte engagement.
comments.ContrastAmplificationPattern: Juxtapose the before state and after state in the same visual frame. Split screen, left/right, or temporal animation. The audience must see both states simultaneously so the delta is visceral, not conceptual. The bigger the visual gap, the stronger the conviction. Use the TwoColumnWidget: left column is the before state in muted tones, right column is the after state in brand primary.
comments.HeroStatDominancePattern: One number so striking it carries the entire slide and anchors the audience's memory of the domain. The hero stat should be unexpected, specific, and large enough to provoke disbelief. Examples: '$450M across 16 brands — one substrate.' '$3.5M leaked annually.' '401K facts.' The stat occupies >50% of slide area. Everything else supports it.
comments.InvisibilityThesis: Charlotte is invisible to the end user. The business never changes what it does. The crew still moves furniture. The auctioneer still calls bids. The technician still services compressors. Charlotte does not disrupt the workflow — it observes it. This is the key objection killer: 'nothing changes for your people.' Emphasize this on every solution slide.
comments.CrossDomainValidation: The same five primitives (NODE, EDGE, METRIC, SIGNAL, PROTOCOL) work in industrial services, premium retail, livestock auctions, rare instruments, moving logistics, manufacturing, genetics, and swine farming. Proving this across 8 domains is the moat argument. No competitor can claim cross-domain validation at this breadth. Show the domain grid: 8 cards, same substrate, different industries.
comments.CompoundMoatPattern: Each new domain Charlotte enters makes the platform more valuable for all existing domains. Cross-domain pattern recognition is impossible to replicate without cross-domain data. The moat is not code — it is the accumulated substrate across industries. A competitor would need to win 8 different industries simultaneously to match Charlotte's intelligence. This is the closing argument.
comments.PEPartner: Private equity partners evaluating Charlotte as portfolio infrastructure. Care about: revenue aggregation, EBITDA visibility, portfolio unification, cross-company intelligence, reporting automation. Lead with ISG narrative. Show the $450M unification story. Emphasize InfrastructureArc.
comments.IndustryPartner: Domain operators evaluating Charlotte for their specific industry. Care about: domain expertise proof, competitive advantage, no workflow disruption, implementation timeline. Lead with the domain-matched narrative. Show the before/after contrast for their exact industry. Emphasize InvisibilityThesis — nothing changes for their people.
comments.SmallBusinessOwner: Owner-operators of sub-$10M businesses. Care about: affordability, invisibility to staff, immediate tangible value, no training required, no IT department needed. Lead with All State or Top Tier narrative. Show transformation from zero data to full observability. Emphasize SeedArc with concrete dollar recovery.
comments.TechnicalAudience: Engineers, architects, and technical evaluators. Care about: five primitive architecture, KRF substrate, temporal/spatial spine, valuation layer, dive line traceability. Lead with the architectural thesis. Show the valuation chain. Emphasize that every conclusion has a deterministic trace — no black-box reasoning.
comments.audienceRespondsto: (audienceRespondsto ?Audience ?Pattern) — this audience segment is most persuaded by this narrative pattern.
comments.PortfolioStat: Aggregate statistics across all 8 domain narratives. The portfolio itself is the proof — 8 different industries, one substrate, $2.5M+ in contracts plus a $100M fund target. No other platform can claim cross-domain validation at this breadth. These numbers populate the Traction slide in the CharlotteArc.

files.purpose: Default protocols — the rules that govern graph evolution

comments.SignalArrival: Fires when a new SIGNAL is placed on a METRIC line.
comments.TimeElapsed: Fires when a duration has passed since a reference point.
comments.ThresholdCrossed: Fires when a METRIC value crosses a defined bound.
comments.StateChanged: Fires when a NODE transitions lifecycle state.
comments.ManualInvocation: Fires when the observer explicitly triggers the protocol.

files.purpose: Presentation knowledge — how Charlotte tells stories to humans

comments.SlideType: A category of pitch deck slide defined by its rhetorical function.
comments.CoverSlide: Identity. Company name, tagline, logo. First impression. Establishes brand.
comments.TableOfContentsSlide: Orientation. Numbered section overview. Sets expectations for narrative arc.
comments.ProblemSlide: Tension. Articulates pain point with evidence. Makes audience feel the gap.
comments.SolutionSlide: Resolution. How the product fills the gap. Clear value proposition.
comments.HowItWorksSlide: Mechanism. Product flow, architecture, or step-by-step process.
comments.MarketOpportunitySlide: Scale. TAM/SAM/SOM, market size, growth rates. Proves the prize is worth winning.
comments.TractionSlide: Evidence. Revenue, users, growth charts. Proves the thesis is working.
comments.BusinessModelSlide: Economics. Revenue streams, pricing tiers, unit economics, LTV/CAC.
comments.CompetitiveLandscapeSlide: Positioning. 2x2 matrix, feature comparison, or moat articulation.
comments.TeamSlide: Trust. Founders, advisors, key hires. Why this team wins.
comments.FinancialsSlide: Projection. Revenue forecast, burn rate, path to profitability.
comments.CustomerProofSlide: Validation. Logos, testimonials, case studies, NPS scores.
comments.VisionSlide: Aspiration. Long-term thesis, north star, category creation argument.
comments.ProductDemoSlide: Tangibility. Screenshots, UI mockups, feature highlights.
comments.GoToMarketSlide: Execution. Channels, partnerships, expansion strategy, flywheel.
comments.AskSlide: Request. Funding amount, use of proceeds, round terms.
comments.ClosingSlide: Punctuation. Thank you, contact info, callback to thesis.
comments.WidgetType: An atomic visual component used to render information on a slide.
comments.HeroTextWidget: Large bold statement text. 2-8 words. The single idea the slide communicates.
comments.SubheadWidget: Supporting text beneath hero. 1-2 sentences of context.
comments.BodyTextWidget: Paragraph-length explanation. Used sparingly — decks favor visuals over prose.
comments.QuoteBlockWidget: Customer or press quote with attribution. Builds credibility through voice.
comments.SectionLabelWidget: Numbered section header. e.g. '1. The Problem' or '3. Our Strategy'.
comments.StatBlockWidget: Single large number with small label. The most common widget in pitch decks.
comments.StatGridWidget: 2x2 or 3x2 grid of StatBlocks. Compresses multiple proof points.
comments.GrowthChartWidget: Line chart showing trajectory over time. The 'hockey stick' when present.
comments.BarChartWidget: Vertical or horizontal bar comparison. Revenue by segment, feature usage.
comments.PieChartWidget: Circular allocation chart. Market share, revenue mix, customer segments.
comments.MarketSizeWidget: Concentric circles showing TAM > SAM > SOM with dollar amounts.
comments.TimelineWidget: Horizontal milestone bar. Founding → seed → product → traction → now.
comments.FunnelWidget: Conversion funnel visualization. Top-of-funnel to revenue.
comments.UnitEconomicsWidget: LTV/CAC ratio, payback period, gross margin displayed as metrics.
comments.TeamGridWidget: Circular headshots in a row with name, title, and prior company.
comments.LogoWallWidget: Grid of customer or partner logos. Pure social proof — no text needed.
comments.IconGridWidget: Features or capabilities shown as icon + short label pairs.
comments.ProductScreenshotWidget: Application screenshot with optional callout annotations.
comments.ComparisonMatrixWidget: Feature comparison table or 2x2 positioning quadrant.
comments.FlowDiagramWidget: Step-by-step process. Boxes connected by arrows. Shows mechanism.
comments.PricingTableWidget: Tier columns with features and prices. Shows revenue architecture.
comments.TwoColumnWidget: Left-right layout splitting slide into two related halves.
comments.slideUsesWidget: Asserts that a slide type may contain this widget type.
comments.NarrativeArc: An ordered sequence of slide types that forms a coherent story.
comments.SeedArc: Pre-revenue or early traction. Emphasizes problem severity, solution elegance, and team credibility. 10-13 slides. Used by: Cradle, Spektr, Copy.ai, Kyra. Pattern: Cover Problem Solution HowItWorks Market Traction Team Ask Closing.
comments.SeriesAArc: Post-traction. Leads with momentum, proves product-market fit, shows path to scale. 14-20 slides. Used by: Rippling, Wayflyer, Read AI, Flo, Pennylane. Pattern: Cover Vision Problem Solution Traction Market BusinessModel Competitive Team Financials Ask Closing.
comments.GrowthArc: Revenue-first narrative. Opens with metrics, builds to expansion thesis. 12-16 slides. Used by: Rippling metrics section, Wayflyer financials-forward. Pattern: Cover Traction Market Product BusinessModel GoToMarket Financials Team Ask Closing.
comments.InfrastructureArc: Platform or infrastructure play. Leads with thesis, emphasizes architecture and moat depth. 14-18 slides. Used by: MoonHub, ValidMind, Filigran. Pattern: Cover Problem Vision Solution HowItWorks Market Traction CustomerProof Competitive Team Financials Ask Closing.
comments.CharlotteArc: Charlotte's native arc. Category creation narrative — starts with the thesis that 97% of businesses were built before AI, builds to infinite OS stack, proves with cross-domain validation, closes with compound moat. Pattern: Cover Vision Problem Solution HowItWorks CustomerProof Traction Market BusinessModel Competitive Team Financials Ask Closing.
comments.arcSlideOrder: (arcSlideOrder ?Arc ?SlideType ?Position) — the slide type at position N in the arc.
comments.OneIdeaPerSlide: Every slide communicates exactly one idea. If a slide needs two ideas, it becomes two slides. The audience should be able to state the takeaway in one sentence. Violation rate in successful decks: <5%.
comments.HeroStatDominance: The most important number on any data slide occupies >40% of visual area. Font size 48-96pt. Supporting context in 14-18pt beneath. Observed in 95% of traction slides across all 100+ decks.
comments.ProblemBeforeSolution: The problem slide always precedes the solution slide. The audience must feel the pain before seeing the cure. Exception: Growth Arc opens with traction when problem is already known to the audience.
comments.ShowDontTell: Screenshots, charts, and logos outperform prose. Average text-to-visual ratio in successful decks: 30/70. Decks with >60% text raised smaller rounds on average.
comments.TenSlideRule: Core narrative should be expressible in 10 slides. Additional slides are appendix material. Median deck length: 13 slides. Mode: 10. Range: 8-35. Decks >20 slides are overwhelmingly Series B+.
comments.SocialProofPlacement: Logo walls and customer quotes appear in the first half of the deck when available. Position: after solution, before financials. LogoWall is the single most space-efficient trust builder.
comments.ProgressiveDisclosure: Information complexity increases through the deck. Cover is simplest. Financials are most complex. Each slide adds one layer of understanding that requires the previous slides as context.
comments.ContrastAmplification: The delta between problem state and solution state should be maximized. Best decks make the current situation feel absurd and the proposed solution feel inevitable. Wayflyer: 'Traditional finance takes weeks. We fund in 24 hours.'
comments.AnchoringWithNumbers: Lead with the largest defensible number. TAM before SAM. Revenue before user count. The first number the audience sees becomes the anchor against which all subsequent numbers are evaluated.
comments.NarrativeCallback: The closing slide echoes the cover slide's thesis. Creates narrative closure. Filigran: opens and closes with logo and tagline. Wayflyer: 'Where eCommerce takes off' on both first and last slide.
comments.VCPartner: Optimizes for: market size, growth rate, team pedigree, category creation potential.
comments.PEOperator: Optimizes for: unit economics, margin structure, integration cost, portfolio fit.
comments.StrategicPartner: Optimizes for: technical compatibility, mutual value creation, implementation timeline.
comments.TechnicalBuyer: Optimizes for: architecture, API surface, security, performance benchmarks.
comments.ExecutiveBuyer: Optimizes for: ROI, time-to-value, competitive risk, status quo cost.
comments.DataBinding: A rule mapping Charlotte substrate data to presentation content.
comments.DeckGenerationProtocol: Master protocol for generating a pitch deck from Charlotte substrate data. Input: a business NODE and a NarrativeArc. Output: an ordered sequence of slides, each populated with widgets bound to the business's substrate data. Steps: 1. Select arc based on business stage and audience 2. For each slide position in the arc, instantiate the slide type 3. For each slide, select widgets from slideUsesWidget 4. For each widget, bind data from the business substrate via canPopulate 5. Apply rhetorical patterns to filter and order content 6. Render using the widget library (tools/pitch-engine/)
comments.MaxThreeColors: Primary + secondary + accent. Never more than 3 colors per slide.
comments.WhitespaceRatio: Minimum 40% whitespace per slide. Content should breathe.
comments.TypeHierarchy: Three levels only: Hero (36-64pt), Body (16-20pt), Caption (10-13pt).
comments.ConsistentAlignment: Left-align text. Center-align single hero statements. Never justify.
comments.BrandPersistence: Logo or wordmark visible on every slide. Small, bottom-right or top-left. 24-36px.

files.purpose: Charlotte's knowledge of the vis.gl visualization ecosystem

comments.VisualizationFramework: A software framework in the vis.gl ecosystem for rendering data visually.
comments.RenderingEngine: A low-level graphics engine that powers visualization frameworks.
comments.LayerType: A deck.gl layer class that renders a specific type of visual element.
comments.CoreLayer: Fundamental deck.gl layers for common visualization patterns.
comments.AggregationLayer: Layers that bin or aggregate data into spatial summaries.
comments.GeoLayer: Layers optimized for geographic and tiled data sources.
comments.MeshLayer: Layers that render 3D meshes and scenegraph objects.
comments.DataLoader: A loaders.gl module for parsing spatial and tabular data formats.
comments.SpatialIndex: A hierarchical spatial indexing system for geospatial data.
comments.AnimationTool: A tool for capturing or replaying visualization animations.
comments.EditingTool: A tool for interactive geometry editing on map visualizations.
comments.MathLibrary: A library providing math primitives for geospatial and 3D computation.
comments.DataShape: A structural pattern in data that determines appropriate visualization.
comments.DeckGL: WebGL2/WebGPU-powered framework for large-scale data visualization. The core of the vis.gl ecosystem with 33 layer types.
comments.KeplerGL: Geospatial analysis tool built on deck.gl. Provides a full UI for exploring location data without code.
comments.LumaGL: High-performance WebGL2/WebGPU rendering engine. Powers deck.gl and all vis.gl visual output.
comments.LoadersGL: Framework-agnostic loaders for 3D tiles, point clouds, GeoJSON, CSV, and 50+ spatial formats.
comments.MathGL: 3D and geospatial math library. Vectors, matrices, bounding boxes, and geodesic calculations.
comments.HubbleGL: Video capture and animation export for deck.gl visualizations. Renders frame-by-frame to video.
comments.NebulaGL: Interactive geometry editing framework for deck.gl. Draw, modify, and delete GeoJSON features on the map.
comments.ReactMapGL: React wrapper for Mapbox GL and MapLibre GL. Provides the base map layer under deck.gl visualizations.
comments.ReactGoogleMaps: React wrapper for Google Maps API. Alternative base map provider for deck.gl overlays.
comments.FlowmapGL: Animated flow visualization on maps. Renders origin-destination data as curved, animated lines.
comments.ProbeGL: Debugging and profiling toolkit for deck.gl applications. Performance monitoring and GPU inspection.
comments.PyDeck: Python bindings for deck.gl. Enables Jupyter notebook and standalone HTML visualization from Python.
comments.H3SpatialIndex: Uber's hexagonal hierarchical spatial index. 16 resolution levels covering the globe.
comments.ArcLayer: Renders raised arcs between source-target coordinate pairs. Ideal for origin-destination flows.
comments.BitmapLayer: Renders georeferenced bitmap images as map overlays. Used for satellite imagery and raster tiles.
comments.ColumnLayer: Renders extruded cylinders at geographic positions. 3D bar charts on maps.
comments.GeoJsonLayer: Renders GeoJSON features: points, lines, and polygons with automatic styling.
comments.GridCellLayer: Renders individual grid cells as extruded rectangles. Building block for grid aggregation.
comments.IconLayer: Renders icons from a texture atlas at geographic positions. Markers, pins, symbols.
comments.LineLayer: Renders flat lines between coordinate pairs. Simpler and faster than ArcLayer for 2D connections.
comments.PathLayer: Renders polylines from arrays of coordinates. Routes, trails, trajectories.
comments.PointCloudLayer: Renders large point cloud datasets in 3D. LiDAR data, depth scans.
comments.PolygonLayer: Renders filled and extruded polygons. Geographic boundaries, building footprints.
comments.ScatterplotLayer: Renders circles at geographic positions. The most common layer for point data.
comments.SolidPolygonLayer: Renders filled polygons without stroke. Higher performance than PolygonLayer for solid fills.
comments.TextLayer: Renders text labels at geographic positions. Collision detection prevents overlap.
comments.ContourLayer: Renders density contour lines or filled isobands from point data. Topographic-style output.
comments.GridLayer: Bins points into a rectangular grid and renders as extruded columns. Spatial histogram.
comments.HeatmapLayer: Renders point density as a continuous color gradient. GPU-accelerated kernel density estimation.
comments.HexagonLayer: Bins points into hexagonal cells and renders as extruded hexagons. Avoids rectangular grid bias.
comments.ScreenGridLayer: Bins points into a screen-space grid. Resolution adapts to zoom level.
comments.A5Layer: Renders data indexed by the A5 geospatial indexing system.
comments.GeohashLayer: Renders data indexed by geohash strings as rectangular cells.
comments.GreatCircleLayer: Renders great circle arcs between points. Accurate long-distance connections on the globe.
comments.H3ClusterLayer: Renders clusters of H3 hexagons merged into polygons. Aggregated regional views.
comments.H3HexagonLayer: Renders individual H3 hexagonal cells. Native integration with Uber's H3 spatial index.
comments.MVTLayer: Renders Mapbox Vector Tiles. Efficient streaming of pre-tiled vector data.
comments.QuadkeyLayer: Renders data indexed by Bing Maps quadkey system as rectangular tiles.
comments.S2Layer: Renders data indexed by Google's S2 geometry cells. Hierarchical spherical indexing.
comments.TerrainLayer: Renders terrain meshes from elevation data. 3D topographic surfaces.
comments.TileLayer: Manages loading and rendering of tiled data. Base class for MVT, terrain, and raster tiles.
comments.Tile3DLayer: Renders OGC 3D Tiles datasets. Buildings, city models, massive point clouds.
comments.TripsLayer: Renders animated trajectories along timestamped paths. Vehicle tracking, migration patterns.
comments.SimpleMeshLayer: Renders instanced 3D meshes at geographic positions. Custom 3D markers.
comments.ScenegraphLayer: Renders glTF 3D models at geographic positions. Full scenegraph with animations.
comments.PointData: Records with latitude/longitude coordinates. The most common spatial data shape.
comments.ArcData: Records with source and target coordinates. Origin-destination pairs, network edges.
comments.TrajectoryData: Records with coordinates and timestamps. Moving objects traced over time.
comments.DensityData: Large point datasets where individual points are less important than spatial density.
comments.PolygonData: Records with polygon geometries. Boundaries, regions, building footprints.
comments.IndexedData: Data keyed by spatial index tokens. H3 hexagons, S2 cells, geohashes, quadkeys.
comments.MeshData: 3D geometry data. Vertices, faces, normals. Point clouds, terrain, 3D models.
comments.TiledData: Pre-tiled data served as map tiles. Vector tiles, raster tiles, 3D tiles.
comments.rendersWith: The rendering engine that powers a visualization framework.
comments.composedOf: A layer type available within a visualization framework.
comments.poweredBy: The engine dependency that a framework requires at runtime.
comments.visualizesDataShape: The data shape that a layer is designed to render.
comments.supportsRealTime: Whether a framework supports real-time data streaming and updates.
comments.capturesVideo: The tool captures frame-by-frame video of a visualization.
comments.editsGeometry: The tool enables interactive editing of geometry data.
comments.ChartType: A 2D canvas chart in Charlotte's charting library. 34 types across 8 categories, zero external dependencies.
comments.TimeSeriesChart: Charts for temporal trends, decomposition, and cumulative views.
comments.ComparisonChart: Charts for ranking, profiling, and before/after comparison.
comments.DistributionChart: Charts for statistical distribution: quartiles, density, and spread.
comments.FinancialChart: Charts for OHLC, technical analysis, and financial time series.
comments.FlowCompositionChart: Charts for flow, hierarchy, and proportional composition.
comments.ActivityChart: Charts for engagement patterns, heatmaps, and temporal activity streams.
comments.NetworkTerritoryChart: Charts for spatial, relational, and goal-tracking data.
comments.AdvancedAnalyticsChart: Charts for multi-band compression, correlation, and signal quality.
comments.LineChart: Multi-series line with Catmull-Rom spline interpolation. Core temporal visualization for trends and comparisons across time.
comments.BarChart: Vertical, horizontal, grouped, and stacked variants. Categorical comparison with configurable bar radius and gap ratios.
comments.AreaChart: Filled region beneath a line. Emphasizes volume and magnitude over time with gradient fills.
comments.StackedAreaChart: Multiple series stacked vertically to show composition over time. Total height encodes cumulative value.
comments.SparklineChart: Compact inline trend for stat cards and table cells. Minimal chrome, maximum information density.
comments.GaugeChart: Circular arc progress indicator. Single-value visualization against a target or range.
comments.WaterfallChart: Sequential additive/subtractive bars showing how initial value decomposes into final. Revenue-to-profit breakdowns.
comments.DonutChart: Ring chart with configurable inner radius. Pie when innerRadius=0. Segment gaps, percentage labels, center widgets.
comments.BumpChart: Rank progression over time. Lines connect rank positions across periods, revealing competitive dynamics.
comments.SlopeChart: Two-point comparison showing before/after value shift. Minimal encoding for directional change.
comments.RadarChart: Multi-axis polygon profile on radial grid. Compares entities across 6+ dimensions simultaneously.
comments.ParallelCoordinatesChart: Multi-dimensional data with vertical parallel axes. Cross-axis line patterns reveal clusters and outliers.
comments.LollipopChart: Dot-and-line combination. Cleaner than bar charts for sparse categorical data with precise value reading.
comments.DumbbellChart: Range between two points per category. Gap encoding for before/after, min/max, or target/actual.
comments.BoxPlotChart: Five-number summary: min, Q1, median, Q3, max with outlier dots. Quartile structure at a glance.
comments.ViolinPlotChart: Kernel density estimation rendered as symmetric shape. Distribution shape visible where box plots show only quartiles.
comments.HistogramChart: Binned frequency distribution with optional KDE overlay. Per-group variants for multi-population comparison.
comments.ScatterPlotChart: Individual points in 2D space. Optional bubble sizing for third dimension. Correlation and clustering.
comments.CandlestickChart: OHLC with wicks and colored bodies. Green/red encoding for gain/loss. Standard financial time series.
comments.BollingerBandsChart: Moving average with confidence envelope at plus/minus two sigma. Volatility and trend strength indicator.
comments.SankeyDiagram: Node-to-node flow with proportional link width. Source to destination through intermediate stages.
comments.FunnelChart: Pipeline narrowing through sequential stages. Conversion rate from wide top to narrow bottom.
comments.MarimekkoChart: Two-dimensional composition: width encodes one variable, height another. Market share by region and segment.
comments.TreemapChart: Proportional rectangular space allocation using squarified layout. Hierarchical part-of-whole with drill-down.
comments.ContributionHeatmap: 52-week by 7-day grid with intensity coloring. GitHub-style activity calendar with cell hover tooltips.
comments.StreamChart: Stacked area flow centered on baseline. Organic channel mix over time with smooth category transitions.
comments.NetworkGraphChart: Force-directed node graph with weighted edges and cluster grouping. Drag, zoom, collision detection.
comments.ChoroplethMap: Geographic region shading by data intensity. State/county/country boundaries with sequential color scales.
comments.TimelineChart: Gantt-style horizontal bars for project phases. Status indicators, dependencies, milestone markers.
comments.RingChart: Concentric progress rings for multi-metric goals. Each ring represents independent progress toward a target.
comments.ProgressChart: Linear progress bars with status coloring. Multiple items compared side-by-side against targets.
comments.BulletChart: Actual vs target with qualitative range bands. Stephen Few's design for compact KPI dashboards.
comments.HorizonChart: Multi-band magnitude compression. 4 color bands fold large value ranges into compact vertical space. 10+ metrics in the height of one line chart.
comments.CorrelationMatrixChart: Pearson r between signal pairs as color-coded grid. Symmetric matrix with diagonal identity.
comments.CategoricalData: Named categories with numeric values. Bar, lollipop, donut charts.
comments.TimeSeriesData: Timestamped numeric values. Line, area, sparkline, candlestick charts.
comments.RankedData: Ordinal position across periods. Bump and slope charts.
comments.MultiDimensionalData: Multiple numeric dimensions per entity. Radar, parallel coordinates.
comments.StatisticalData: Raw observations requiring distribution analysis. Box plot, violin, histogram.
comments.FlowData: Source-to-destination records with magnitude. Sankey, funnel charts.
comments.HierarchicalData: Nested parent-child records with values. Treemap, marimekko charts.
comments.OHLCData: Open-high-low-close price records with volume. Candlestick, bollinger bands.
comments.ActivityData: Date-stamped event counts or intensities. Contribution heatmap, stream charts.
comments.GraphData: Nodes and edges with optional weights. Network graph, force-directed layout.
comments.SpatialRegionData: Geographic boundaries with associated values. Choropleth maps.
comments.ProgressData: Current value against target. Gauge, ring, progress, bullet charts.
comments.CorrelationData: Pairwise signal comparisons. Correlation matrix, horizon charts.
comments.CharlotteChartsLibrary: Charlotte Charts v3.3: zero-dependency Canvas 2D charting library. 34 chart types, 6 brand themes (Platform, SomeAI, Sounder, ISG, Richard Enterprises, All State), mobile-first responsive, Catmull-Rom spline interpolation, Figma-matched card styling.
comments.ParticleVisualization: A 3D particle point cloud rendered in brand palette. Charlotte's fallback visualization for complex relational data. When conventional charts fail, reduce to dust particles — cluster density reveals structure, neural synapse edges reveal connections.
comments.MathSurface: A parametric 3D mathematical surface sampled as a point cloud. Each brand gets unique mathematical identity art — same geometry engine, distinct visual DNA through brand color mapping.
comments.ParticleRenderStyle: A coloring strategy for mapping brand palette onto depth-sorted particles.
comments.LorenzAttractor: Chaotic attractor. sigma=10, rho=28, beta=8/3. The butterfly — deterministic chaos.
comments.TrefoilKnot: Simplest nontrivial knot. Tube around a (2,3)-torus knot curve with Frenet frame.
comments.MobiusStrip: Non-orientable surface with one side and one boundary. Half-twist ruled surface.
comments.KleinBottle: Non-orientable closed surface. Self-intersects in 3D — the bottle with no inside.
comments.TorusKnot35: Torus knot (p=3, q=5). Winds 3 times around the torus hole, 5 times through it.
comments.DiniSurface: Surface of constant negative curvature. Pseudosphere unwound into a helical scroll.
comments.EnneperSurface: Self-intersecting minimal surface. Saddle-like with nine-fold symmetry.
comments.SphericalHarmonics: Angular solutions to Laplace's equation on the sphere. l=4, m=3 produces petal lobes.
comments.Catenoid: Minimal surface of revolution. Soap film between two coaxial rings.
comments.Helicoid: Ruled minimal surface. Infinite spiral staircase — the only ruled minimal surface besides the plane.
comments.Seashell: Logarithmic spiral tube. Exponential growth with cross-section — natural shell geometry.
comments.BreatherSurface: Pseudospherical surface from soliton solutions of sine-Gordon equation. Rippling wave topology.
comments.RomanSurface: Steiner surface. Projection of the real projective plane into 3D with tetrahedral symmetry.
comments.HeartSurface: Cardioid-family parametric surface. Symbolic geometry for non-technical audiences.
comments.FigureEightKnot: The unique prime knot with 4 crossings. Tube around a (2,3)x(3,4) winding curve.
comments.GyroidApprox: Triply periodic minimal surface. cos(x)sin(y)+cos(y)sin(z)+cos(z)sin(x)≈0. Found in butterfly wings.
comments.Mandelbulb: 3D Mandelbrot fractal. Power-8 spherical iteration — fractal boundary in three dimensions.
comments.SpringHelix: Helical tube with 5 coils. Circular cross-section swept along helix curve.
comments.CrossCap: Immersion of the real projective plane. Self-intersects at a pinch point.
comments.CliffordTorus: Flat torus living in S^3. Stereographic projection from 4D — the perfectly symmetric torus.
comments.NeonDualTone: Depth-interpolated dual-tone. Front=secondary, cross at 60% to primary→accent. Brand chromatic identity.
comments.MonochromeStyle: Single-hue primary with alpha modulated by depth. Clean, technical presence.
comments.DepthGradient: Three-band gradient: secondary→primary→accent→primary. Full palette expression through depth.
comments.KNNGraphConstruction: k-nearest-neighbors adjacency from 3D point positions. Each particle connects to k nearest neighbors — undirected graph emerges from spatial proximity. The neural synapse view of complex data: nodes are particles, edges are proximity connections. This is Charlotte's graph-as-dust-cloud metaphor.
comments.AlgorithmicTraversal: A* pathfinding over the KNN particle graph. Explored edges appear sequentially in animation — the algorithm becomes visible as a glowing traversal through the point cloud. Exported as Lottie JSON for web playback.
comments.GeoParticlesLibrary: GeoParticles: parametric 3D math surfaces rendered as particle point clouds in brand design systems. 20 surfaces, 3 styles, 10 brand palettes. KNN graph construction + A* traversal + Lottie export. Zero dependencies. Every business gets unique mathematical identity art — same geometry engine, distinct visual DNA.
comments.PitchEngine: A deck compiler. Structured business data in, narrative arc selected, presentation compiled automatically. The engine selects widgets from 4 categories mapped to Charlotte's five primitives: Text widgets    → NODE     (hero, subhead, body, quote, section label) Data widgets    → METRIC   (stat block, stat grid, bar, pie, TAM circles, timeline, unit economics, growth chart) Entity widgets  → NODE     (team grid, logo wall, icon grid, screenshot) Structure widgets → EDGE/PROTOCOL (comparison matrix, flow diagram, pricing table, before/after split) 21 widgets total. The Before/After split is Charlotte's signature — red pain on the left, green resolution on the right.
comments.NarrativeArc: A storytelling sequence — the plan that determines what gets said and in what order. Each arc is optimized for a specific fundraising stage or sales motion. Arc selection is the most important decision in deck compilation.
comments.SeedArc: Pre-revenue. 9 sections. Problem severity → solution elegance → team. Used when the story is 'we found something broken and we know how to fix it.' Pattern: Cradle, Spektr, Copy.ai, Kyra.
comments.SeriesAArc: Post-traction. 13 sections. Vision → PMF proof → path to scale. Used when the story is 'we proved it works, now fund the machine.' Pattern: Rippling, Wayflyer, Read AI, Flo, Pennylane.
comments.GrowthArc: Revenue-first. 11 sections. Metrics lead, expansion thesis follows. Used when traction speaks for itself and the numbers open the door.
comments.InfrastructureArc: Platform play. 14 sections. Thesis → architecture → moat depth. Used when the story is 'we're building the layer everything else runs on.' Pattern: MoonHub, ValidMind, Filigran.
comments.CharlotteArc: Category creation. 15 sections. The thesis that 97% of businesses were built before AI. Before/After as the core proof pattern. Vision → BeforeAfter → Problem → Solution → HowItWorks → Proof. Charlotte's own arc — the one that creates the category.
comments.TrainedBusinessProfile: A real business whose data was used to train and validate the pitch engine. Each profile contains the full structured input needed to compile a deck in any narrative arc.
comments.ISGProfile: Industrial Service Group. $450M revenue, 16 brands, 42 locations, 259K+ SKUs, 200+ technicians. $1.4M/2yr contract. Industry: MRO. Before: 16 islands of data. After: unified equipment graph. The enterprise beachhead — PE portfolio unification.
comments.CardVaultProfile: CardVault by Tom Brady. $35M revenue, 12 locations, 338% growth, $33B market. $510K/24mo contract. Industry: Sports Collectibles. Before: 12 retail islands. After: unified collector graph. The celebrity-brand retail play.
comments.AllStateProfile: All State Manufacturing. $2.2M revenue, ~10 employees, founded 1975. $105K/24mo contract. Industry: Micro market fixtures. Before: 50 years of tribal knowledge. After: observable manufacturing. The '97%' archetype — profitable, invisible, zero digital presence.
comments.SCOnlineProfile: SC Online Sales. 40K+ auctions, 5 species, 10K+ users, 3 platforms. $135K/24mo contract. Industry: Livestock auctions. Before: species-siloed. After: cross-species buyer intelligence. The multi-sided marketplace play.
comments.WendtProfile: The Wendt Group / ShowPig.com. 12K+ online auctions, 6.5K+ live, 65K+ breeders, 4 platforms. $156K/24mo. Industry: Swine genetics. Before: no crossbred pedigree system. After: AI-built ancestry. The industry-infrastructure play.
comments.PPPProfile: PPP Instruments / Prier Violins. 21 instruments, $5.3M portfolio, 88.3% appreciation, $100M fund target. Industry: Alternative assets. Before: paper provenance. After: instrument identity graph. The alternative-asset intelligence play.
comments.TopTierProfile: Top Tier Moving. $14.4M billed, $10.9M collected (75.7%), 98 crew, 10,606 jobs, 52 states. $93K/24mo. Industry: Interstate moving. Before: $3.5M revenue leakage. After: crew baseball cards + collection intel. The operational-recovery play — ROI from day one.
comments.SounderProfile: Sounder. 3 registries (NSR/CPS/Tamworth), 77,982 breeders, 401,788 KRF facts, $1.13M tracked sales. Internal deployment. Before: disconnected registries. After: unified swine genetics OS. The first vertical — Charlotte's own proof of concept.
comments.CharlottePitchEngine: Charlotte Pitch Engine: a trained deck compiler. Structured business data in, narrative arc selected, presentation compiled automatically. 21 composable widgets, 5 narrative arcs, Before/After as signature. Trained on 8 real business profiles across industrial services, sports collectibles, manufacturing, livestock, alternative assets, logistics, and swine genetics. Neural network background animation. Zero external dependencies.

files.purpose: Default part-of hierarchies — composition and containment

comments.partOf: X is a part of Y. Transitive, antisymmetric, reflexive.

files.purpose: Default typed relations — the edge vocabulary

comments.OWNS: A owns B. Implies responsibility and authority.
comments.MEMBER_OF: A is a member of group B.
comments.PARENT_OF: A is a biological parent of B.
comments.SIRE_OF: A is the sire (father) of B.
comments.DAM_OF: A is the dam (mother) of B.
comments.NEXT: A is immediately followed by B on the temporal spine.
comments.PRECEDES: A occurs before B in time.
comments.LOCATED_AT: A is physically located at B.
comments.ADJACENT_TO: A is adjacent to B in space. Symmetric.
comments.CAUSES: A causes B. Directional, not necessarily sufficient.
comments.ENABLES: A enables B. Necessary but not sufficient.
comments.DERIVED_FROM: A is derived from B. Provenance chain.
comments.GOVERNS: PROTOCOL A governs the behavior of B.
comments.MEASURES: METRIC A measures dimension of NODE B.

files.purpose: Default is-a hierarchies — the backbone of structural knowledge
CHARLOTTE OPERATING SYSTEM — BOOT IMAGE
The 27 reference domains bounding Charlotte's knowledge surface

comments.FoundationsCluster: Formal logic, graph theory, topology, game theory, systems architecture — the mathematical and structural bedrock.
comments.KnowledgePrimitives: Structural, declarative, procedural, heuristic & meta knowledge. The five vertices of the convex hull itself.
comments.FormalLogic: Propositional logic, first-order logic, lambda calculus & Lisp. The inference engine beneath Charlotte's KRF substrate.
comments.GraphTheory: Knowledge graphs, ontologies & graph databases. The relational fabric of NODE-EDGE primitives.
comments.Topology: Algebraic topology, topological data analysis & higher dimensions. Shape-invariant reasoning for spatial substrate.
comments.GameTheory: Nash equilibrium, mechanism design & evolutionary strategy. Multi-agent decision theory for PROTOCOL primitives.
comments.SystemsArchitecture: Distributed systems, DDD & event-driven design. The engineering patterns behind Charlotte's container model.
comments.CognitionSignalCluster: Cognitive science, signal processing, neuroscience — the observer's internal model and how signals become meaning.
comments.CognitiveScience: Predictive coding, Bayesian brain & resonance. Charlotte's observer model — perception as inference.
comments.SignalProcessing: Time series, frequency domain & drift detection. The math behind SIGNAL primitives and METRIC computation.
comments.Neuroscience: Neural geometry reference hub. How biological networks encode spatial and temporal structure.
comments.DataComputeCluster: Temporal databases, spatial computing, atomic design — how data is stored, indexed, and rendered.
comments.TemporalDatabases: Event sourcing, bitemporal modeling & CQRS. The storage theory behind Charlotte's temporal spine.
comments.SpatialComputing: GIS, spatial databases & geospatial algorithms. The indexing theory behind Charlotte's spatial planes.
comments.AtomicDesign: Component hierarchy & design systems. Atoms-molecules-organisms for Charlotte's interface layer.
comments.BiologyCluster: Biomimicry, entomology, livestock science, nature-inspired algorithms, swarm intelligence, ocean science — intelligence observed in living systems.
comments.Biomimicry: Principles, methodology & case studies. Design by emulating nature's time-tested patterns.
comments.Entomology: Insect biology, pollination & biomimicry. Joseph's domain — swarm behavior and emergent coordination.
comments.LivestockScience: Genetics, breeding, reproduction & show industry. The domain knowledge behind Sounder and swine genetics.
comments.NatureInspiredAlgorithms: Evolutionary computation & swarm intelligence. Optimization strategies borrowed from biology.
comments.SwarmIntelligence: Rubenstein's Kilobots, flocking, stigmergy & collective construction. Charlotte's origin curriculum — local rules producing global order.
comments.OceanScience: Marine biology, oceanography, coral reefs & deep sea. Sea Lion's domain — swarm observation beneath the surface.
comments.BioEngineeringCluster: Bio-architecture, bio-robotics, bio-locomotion, bio-optics, bio-surfaces, biomimetic materials, structural biomimetics, spider silk, ecological systems design — engineering that borrows from nature's 3.8 billion years of R&D.
comments.BioArchitecture: Termite ventilation, shells & tensegrity. Buildings that breathe, flex, and self-regulate.
comments.BioInspiredRobotics: Soft robotics, legged robots & swarm systems. Machines built on biological movement principles.
comments.BioLocomotion: Flight, swimming & collective motion. How bodies move through fluid, air, and terrain.
comments.BioOptics: Structural color, bioluminescence & camouflage. Light manipulation strategies evolved by nature.
comments.BioSurfaces: Superhydrophobicity, gecko adhesion & shark skin. Surface engineering from micro-scale biology.
comments.BiomimeticMaterials: Self-healing, shape memory & hierarchical composites. Materials designed by studying biological structures.
comments.StructuralBiomimetics: Natural composites, silk, nacre & bone. Load-bearing architectures from biology.
comments.SpiderSilk: Silk biology, biomaterials & husbandry. The strongest biological fiber — tensile strength meets elasticity.
comments.EcologicalSystemsDesign: Circular economy & regenerative design. Closed-loop systems that mirror ecosystem nutrient cycles.
comments.ConvexHullLibrary: 27 reference domains across 5 clusters: Foundations (6), Cognition & Signal (3), Data & Compute (3), Biology (6), Bio-Engineering (9). Together they bound the knowledge surface Charlotte can reason about. Interior points are weighted combinations of these boundary domains.

files.purpose: The convex hull of knowledge — bounding surface theorem

comments.ConvexHullOfKnowledge: Any knowledge artifact K can be expressed as: K = w1*Structural + w2*Declarative + w3*Procedural + w4*Heuristic + w5*Meta where w1..w5 >= 0 and w1 + w2 + w3 + w4 + w5 = 1. The five types are the vertices. All knowledge is interior.
comments.BreedingDecision: Structural: sire-dam-litter relationships. Declarative: genotype, phenotype, breed registry. Procedural: breeding protocols, gestation rules. Heuristic: breeder intuition, rule-of-thumb selection. Meta: confidence in genomic predictions.
comments.ViolinAuthentication: Structural: provenance chain (maker → dealer → owner). Declarative: measurements, wood analysis, label text. Procedural: authentication protocol steps. Heuristic: expert's eye, tonal quality assessment. Meta: certainty of attribution, known gaps in provenance.
comments.LogisticsDispatch: Structural: crew-truck-job assignments. Declarative: addresses, weights, inventory lists. Procedural: dispatch workflow, routing rules. Heuristic: estimated time, crew capacity judgment. Meta: tracking what information is missing from the manifest.
comments.VenueExperience: Structural: guest-event-venue relationships. Declarative: capacity, schedule, pricing. Procedural: entry protocols, queue management. Heuristic: crowd mood, wait time estimates. Meta: real-time confidence in occupancy counts.

files.purpose: Formalization of the ATLAS_KNOWLEDGE_PRIMITIVES diagram

comments.(primaryPrimitive MetaKnowledge None): Meta knowledge has no single primitive. It is the system reflecting on itself: nodes about nodes, edges about edges, protocols about protocols.

files.purpose: Physical space — latitude, longitude, elevation

comments.GeospatialPlane: The physical space plane. Coordinates are latitude, longitude, and elevation. Every physical entity has a position here.
comments.distanceBetween: (distanceBetween A B D) — the geodesic distance between A and B is D.
comments.nearTo: A is geospatially near B. Proximity threshold is domain-specific.

files.purpose: Kd-space — the conceptual space where Charlotte lives

comments.TheoreticalPlane: The Kd-dimensional conceptual space. Every entity, metric, and signal has a position here. The temporal spine is the primary axis. Charlotte lives on this plane, observing and placing signals on metric lines.
comments.KdSpace: A K-dimensional vector space where K = number of active metric dimensions.
comments.KdDimension: One axis of the Kd-space. Maps 1:1 to a METRIC definition.
comments.KdCoordinate: A position in Kd-space. A vector of values, one per dimension.
comments.TemporalSpineAxis: The primary axis of Kd-space. Time. The spine on which the observer travels from epoch to millisecond. Every other dimension hangs off this axis like ribs off a backbone.
comments.MetricLine: A line in Kd-space running parallel to the temporal spine. Each METRIC has one. The observer places SIGNALs on these lines. The accumulation of signals over time is the observable reality of that dimension.
comments.fullSpatialPosition: The complete spatial address of an entity across all three interwoven planes: where it is physically, where it is in the graph, and where it is in Kd-space.
comments.kdDistance: (kdDistance A B D) — the Euclidean distance between A and B in Kd-space.

files.purpose: Abstract spatial relations — containment, adjacency, connectivity

comments.TopologicalPlane: The relational space plane. Position is defined by connectivity, not coordinates. Two nodes are 'close' if few edges separate them.
comments.ExternallyConnected: Share a boundary but no interior overlap.
comments.PartialOverlap: Overlap but neither contains the other.
comments.NonTangentialProperPart: A is entirely inside B, not touching B's boundary.
comments.graphDistance: (graphDistance A B N) — the shortest path between A and B is N edges.
comments.neighborhood: (neighborhood Node K ResultSet) — all nodes within K edges of Node.
comments.degreeCentrality: (degreeCentrality Node N) — number of edges incident to Node.
comments.betweennessCentrality: (betweennessCentrality Node Score) — fraction of shortest paths passing through Node.

files.purpose: Seed data — 50 US states with convex hulls, centroids,

comments.SpatialEntity: A geographic entity with a convex hull and centroid
comments.USState: A US state or territory - geographic NODE in the spatial substrate
comments.USRegion: A US geographic region grouping states
comments.inRegion: State belongs to a geographic region
comments.hasConvexHull: Ordered convex hull vertices as list of (lng lat) pairs
comments.hasHullPointCount: Number of vertices in the convex hull
comments.cardinalDirectionTo: Cardinal direction from source centroid to target - value is (target direction distance_km)
comments.distanceKm: Great-circle distance between centroids - value is (target distance_km)
comments.Region-W: West region of the United States
comments.Region-MW: Midwest region of the United States
comments.Region-NE: Northeast region of the United States
comments.Region-SE: Southeast region of the United States
comments.Region-SW: Southwest region of the United States
comments.ContinentalUS: The convex hull of the 48 contiguous states plus DC

files.purpose: Epoch boundary encoding and context compression

comments.memoryDepth: How many epochs back the container can unravel. Each level of depth adds 2048 years of accessible history. The cost of deeper memory is the computational cost of recursive decompression.

files.purpose: The epoch system — 2048-year units of time

comments.Epoch: The largest temporal unit. 2048 years. At the boundary, the full context is compressed, encoded, and chained into index 0 of the next epoch. Depth of unraveling = depth of memory.
comments.EpochIndex: Position within the epoch's encoded chain. Index 0 is the blockchain anchor from the previous epoch.
comments.Epoch-0: The current epoch. Begins 1970, ends 4018. We are here.
comments.Epoch-Neg1: The previous epoch. 78 BC to 1970 AD.
comments.memoryDepth: (memoryDepth Container N) — this container can unravel N epochs of history.

files.purpose: Extended temporal ontology — 15 granularity levels, 58 categorical

comments.TemporalDirection: The four directions of temporal navigation. Analogous to cardinal directions in spatial substrate.
comments.Coarser: Toward lower resolution: Day to Month to Year. Zoom out.
comments.Finer: Toward higher resolution: Year to Month to Day. Zoom in.
comments.Earlier: Backward in sequence. Traversing prev edges.
comments.Later: Forward in sequence. Traversing next edges.
comments.TemporalGranularity: A level in the temporal resolution hierarchy. 15 levels from Millennium to Hour.
comments.granularityDirectionTo: From level A, direction D reaches level B. Analogous to cardinalDirectionTo in spatial substrate.
comments.adjacentGranularity: These levels are neighbors in the hierarchy. Analogous to adjacentTo.
comments.containsPerUnit: One unit of A contains ~N units of B
comments.GranYear: A single calendar year. The fundamental human planning unit.
comments.GranHalfYear: 6-month block. H1 (Jan-Jun) or H2 (Jul-Dec). Financial reporting cadence.
comments.GranQuarter: 3-month block. Q1-Q4. The standard business reporting unit.
comments.GranMonth: A single calendar month. Where most human activity is planned.
comments.GranFortnight: 2-week block. Common payroll and sprint cadence.
comments.GranWeek: A single ISO week. The atomic planning unit for most teams.
comments.GranDay: A single calendar day. The central unit of the temporal substrate.
comments.GranHalfDay: AM or PM. 12-hour block. Civil timekeeping unit.
comments.GranShift: 8-hour block. Industrial shift: Morning, Afternoon, Night.
comments.GranHour: A single hour. The finest resolution in this substrate.
comments.TemporalNode: Any node on the temporal spine - a unique point in time or a recurring category
comments.MillenniumNode: A unique millennium, e.g. Millennium-0 (years 0-999). 3 total.
comments.CenturyNode: A unique century, e.g. Century-19 (1900-1999). 21 total.
comments.HalfCenturyNode: A unique 50-year block, e.g. HalfCentury-1950. 41 total.
comments.DecadeNode: A unique decade, e.g. Decade-2020 (2020-2029). 205 total.
comments.YearNode: A unique year, e.g. Year-2025. 2,049 total.
comments.HalfYearNode: A unique half-year, e.g. HalfYear-2025-H1 (Jan-Jun). 4,098 total.
comments.TrimesterNode: A unique 4-month block, e.g. Trimester-2025-T1. 6,147 total.
comments.QuarterNode: A unique quarter, e.g. Quarter-2025-Q1. 8,196 total.
comments.MonthNode: A unique month, e.g. Month-2025-01. 24,588 total.
comments.WeekNode: A unique ISO week, e.g. Week-2025-W03. ~106,862 total.
comments.DayNode: A unique day, e.g. Day-2025-01-15. The central unit. ~748,294 total.
comments.HalfDayNode: A unique AM/PM, e.g. HalfDay-2025-01-15-AM. ~1,496,588 total.
comments.ShiftNode: A unique 8-hour shift, e.g. Shift-2025-01-15-Morning. ~2,244,882 total.
comments.HourNode: A unique hour, e.g. Hour-2025-01-15-14. ~17,959,056 total.
